Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.
Wonderful Citrus D2 was built in 2012 by Ross & Sons. The original construction included the Conditioning and Cold Storage Systems. In 2015, American Incorporated was hired to design and install the refrigeration equipment for Process 3.

In general, Wonderful Citrus D2 refrigeration equipment was designed and installed by licensed contractors in accordance with industry standards at the time of construction. Each system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. Each entrance to a machinery room contains emergency refrigeration shutdown and ventilation controls for use during an emergency situation.
Each ammonia system at Wonderful Citrus D2 consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are not connected to each other, nor co-located such that a release from one system would impact the ability to operate the other systems. As such, Wonderful Citrus D2 has three (3) refrigeration processes.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The Conditioning and Cold Storage Systems operate as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator vessel. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulator vessels through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator in the engine room. From there, it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.
Process 3 operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a liquid feed solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.

e overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

Wonderful Citrus D2 operates a commercial packing and storage facility for clementines in Delano, CA. The facility has three (3) ammonia systems which are named Conditioning, Cold Storage, and Process 3 respectively. 

The systems provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

Conditioning System
¿	(44) Degreening rooms
¿	(4) Whip rooms
Cold Storage System
¿	(2) Cold storage rooms
¿	(1) Precool room
¿	(1) Loading dock
Process 3 
¿	(80) Conditioning rooms

The refrigerated spaces in the Conditioning and Cold Storage systems are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation while Process 3 is equipped with air-cooling evaporators and a pump recirculator as required for pumped overfeed operation. All control valve groups are mounted on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within the three (3) refrigeration machinery rooms or directly outside near the machinery rooms. A partial list of system components includes:

Conditioning System

¿	(2) Evapco PMC Condensers

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Wonderful Citrus D2 has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Wonderful Citrus D2, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Wonderful Citrus D2 has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name           | Process Chemical           | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Conditioning             Anhydrous Ammonia            30,000
Storage                  Anhydrous Ammonia             9,800
Process 3                Anhydrous Ammonia            53,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. 

Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promot

nnual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Wonderful Citrus D2 has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration processes at the Wonderful Citrus D2 facility are an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia processes contain a total charge of approximately 92,600 (LBS). It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active logbook of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Wonderful Citrus D2 has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Wonderful Citrus D2' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 
- California Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 §5192(q)
- Federal Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)

Wonderful Citrus D2 has developed a Hazmat Technician Emergency

Response Team for responding to releases of anhydrous ammonia. Refer to the facility Emergency Response Plan for more information.
Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Wonderful Citrus D2 has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Wonderful Citrus D2 continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Wonderful Citrus D2' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Wonderful Citrus D2' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Wonderful Citrus D2 has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Wonderful Citrus D2 has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Wonderful Citrus D2 now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Wonderful Citrus D2 employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement.
